name: Goldberg–Seymour conjecture
rephrased: In any multigraph, the minimum number of colors needed to color the edges (without adjacent edges sharing the same color) is at most the larger of one plus the highest degree any vertex has, or the average degree of the graph.
implication_form: If G is a multigraph, then χ′(G) ≤ max(1 + Δ(G), Γ(G)).
explained: The Goldberg–Seymour conjecture is a statement in graph theory about edge coloring in multigraphs. It proposes that for any multigraph G, the edge chromatic number χ'(G) (the minimum number of colors needed to color the edges so that no two adjacent edges share the same color) is at most the maximum value between Δ(G) + 1 (where Δ(G) is the maximum degree of G) and Γ(G) (where Γ(G) is the clique number of G, defined as the maximum number of edges incident to any vertex).
